H3.04.03.0.00009; H3.04.03.0.00016 H3.05.00.0.00006 | }} 'Goblet cells'
are glandular simple columnar epithelial cells whose sole function is to secrete
mucin, which dissolves in water to form mucus. They use both apocrine and
merocrine methods for secretion.

The majority of the cell's cytoplasm is occupied by mucinogen granules, except
at the bottom. Rough endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, the nucleus, and other
organelles are concentrated in the basal portion. The apical plasma membrane
projects microvilli to increase surface area for secretion. Recent study
suggests that glycoprotein is located inside goblet cells. It is an organ-
specific antigen in the gut.
